revision.text:
{{Year box}} '''1872 in sports''' describes the year's events in world sport.
==[[American football]]== '''College championship''' * [[NCAA Division I FBS National Football Championship|College football national championship]] – [[Princeton Tigers]] '''Events''' * Five teams compete in the [[1872 college football season]]: {{cfb link|year=1872|team=Columbia Lions|school=Columbia University|title=Columbia}}, {{cfb link|year=1872|team=Rutgers Scarlet Knights|title=Rutgers}}, [[1872 Princeton Tigers football team|Princeton]], [[1872 Stevens Ducks football team|Stevens Tech]] and [[1872 Yale Bulldogs football team|Yale]].
==[[Association football]]== '''International''' * 30 November — [[Scotland national football team|Scotland]] v. [[England national football team|England]] in Glasgow is the [[Scotland v England (1872)|first–ever official football international]]. The match is a goalless draw.
'''England''' * 16 March — inaugural [[1872 FA Cup Final|FA Cup final]]. [[Wanderers F.C.|The Wanderers]] 1–0 [[Royal Engineers A.F.C.|Royal Engineers]] at [[The Oval|Kennington Oval]] in London. The goal is scored by [[Morton Betts]]. In its way, this first final marks the beginning of major competitive football. * The FA rules that the ball must have a circumference of between 68 cm and 71 cm. It must be spherical and must consist of an India rubber bladder enclosed within a casing made of leather or another approved material. Also, the ball must weigh at least 396 grams but no more than 453 grams. The prescribed weight is interesting because leather balls will become notorious for gaining weight when wet: the weight can almost double if the ball gets really soaked.<ref>Among the many stories told about [[Bill Shankly]] is one concerning the introduction of plastic balls in the 1960s. Someone remarked to Shankly that so–and–so was a master of the "banana shot" and could bend the ball through the air. Shankly replied: "Huh! I'd like to see him try bending one of those soggy wet leather things we used to play with. It'd break his bloody ankle!"</ref> '''Scotland''' * February — [[Rangers F.C.]] is formed in Glasgow by four friends. The team's first pitch is on common land at Flesher's Haugh, Glasgow Green.
==[[Baseball]]== '''National championship''' * [[National Association of Professional Base Ball Players]] champion – [[History of the Boston Braves|Boston Red Stockings]] '''Events''' * The [[National Association of Professional Base Ball Players|National Association]] (NA) permits [[pitch (baseball)|pitch]]ing with a wrist snap, practically legalising the [[New York Mutuals]]. * Multiple [[NABBP]] champions [[Brooklyn Eckfords|Eckford]] and [[Brooklyn Atlantics|Atlantic]] from [[Brooklyn, New York]] join the NA but neither will regain prominence. * The original [[History of the Boston Braves|Boston Red Stockings]] win the NA pennant, beginning a four-year run
==[[Boxing]]== '''Events''' * No fights of note take place in 1872. American Champion [[Mike McCoole]] and his challengers are inactive.<ref name="MM">[http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/mccoole.htm Cyber Boxing Zone – Mike McCoole]. Retrieved on 8 November 2009.</ref>
==[[Cricket]]== '''Events''' * An experiment takes place at [[Lord's]] to study the effects of covering the pitch before the start of a match, the first time this is known to have been tried.<ref>Bowen, p.284.</ref> '''England''' * Most runs – [[W. G. Grace]] 1,485 @ 57.11 (HS 170*) * Most wickets – [[James Southerton]] 169 @ 13.07 (BB 8–20)
==[[Golf]]== '''Major tournaments''' * [[1872 Open Championship|British Open]] – [[Tom Morris, Jr.|Tom Morris junior]]
==[[Horse racing]]== '''England''' * [[1872 Grand National|Grand National]] – Casse Tete * [[1,000 Guineas Stakes]] – Reine * [[2,000 Guineas Stakes]] – Prince Charlie * [[Epsom Derby|The Derby]] – [[Cremorne (horse)|Cremorne]] * [[Epsom Oaks|The Oaks]] – Reine * [[St. Leger Stakes]] – Wenlock '''Australia''' * [[Melbourne Cup]] – The Quack '''Canada''' * [[Queen's Plate]] – Fearnaught '''Ireland''' * [[Irish Grand National]] – Scots Grey * [[Irish Derby Stakes]] – Trickstress '''USA''' * [[Belmont Stakes]] – [[Joe Daniels (horse)|Joe Daniels]]
==[[Rowing (sport)|Rowing]]== '''The Boat Race''' * 23 March — [[Cambridge University Boat Club|Cambridge]] wins the 29th [[The Boat Race 1872|Oxford and Cambridge Boat Race]]
==[[Rugby football]]== '''Events''' * [[Wigan Warriors|Wigan RLFC]] founded
==References== {{Reflist}}
==Bibliography== * [[Rowland Bowen]], ''Cricket: A History of its Growth and Development'', Eyre & Spottiswoode, 1970
{{Sports by year 1851 – 1900}}
[[Category:Sports by year]] [[Category:1872 in sports| ]]

revision.text:
{{Distinguish|Personal trainer}} '''Athletic training''' has been recognized by the [[American Medical Association]] (AMA) as an allied health care profession since June 1991."What is an Athletic Trainer?". The Board of Certification Website. 2003 As defined by the Strategic Implementing Team of the National Athletic Trainers' Association (NATA) in August 2007.
"Athletic training is practiced by athletic trainers, health care professionals who collaborate with physicians to optimize activity and participation of patients and clients. Athletic training encompasses the prevention, diagnosis, and intervention of emergency, acute and chronic medical conditions involving impairment, functional limitations and disabilities.""Strategic implementation team defines profession". NATA News (12/2007): 14. 2007.
There are five domains of athletic training listed in the 7th edition (2015) of the Athletic Training Practice Analysis:{{Cite web|url=http://www.bocatc.org/images/stories/resources/pa7-outline-vf.pdf|title=Practice Analysis, 7th ed.|last=Board of Certification|first=|date=2015|website=www.bocatc.org|publisher=|access-date=2016-11-29}}{{Dead link|date=September 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} * Injury and Illness Prevention and Wellness Promotion * Examination, Assessment and Diagnosis * Immediate and Emergency Care * Therapeutic Intervention * Healthcare Administration and Professional Responsibility An athletic trainer functions as an integral member of the health care team in clinics, secondary schools, colleges and universities, professional sports programs, and other athletic health care settings.Prentice, W. (2011). Principles of Athletic Training. New York: McGraw-Hill. == History == Athletic training in the United States began in October 1881 when Harvard University hired James Robinson to work conditioning their football team. At the time, the term "athletic trainer" meant one who worked with track and field athletes. Robinson had worked with track and field athletes and the name "athletic trainer" transferred to those working on conditioning these football players and later other athletes. Athletic trainers began to treat and rehabilitate injuries in order to keep the athletes participating.{{cite book|last=Webber|first=Matt|title=Dropping the Bucket and Sponge|year=2013|publisher=Athletic Training History|location=Prescott, AZ|pages=20–24}} The first major text on athletic training and the care of athletic injuries was called Athletic Training (later changed to The Trainer's Bible) written in 1917 by Samuel E. Bilik.{{cite book|last=Prentice|first=William|title=Principles of Athletic Training: A Competency-Based Approach|year=2011|publisher=McGraw-Hill Humanities/Social Sciences/Languages|location=New York, NY|pages=3, 27, 28}} Early athletic trainers had "no technical knowledge, their athletic training techniques usually consisted of a rub, the application of some type of counterirritant, and occasionally the prescription of various home remedies and poultices".{{cite book|last=Prentice|first=William|title=Principles of Athletic Training: A Competency-Based Approach|year=2011|publisher=McGraw-Hill Humanities/Social Sciences/Languages|location=New York, NY|pages=3, 27, 28}} In 1918, Chuck Cramer started the Cramer Chemical Company (now Cramer Products) that produced a line of products used by athletic trainers and began publishing a newsletter in 1932 entitled The First Aider.{{cite web|title=Cramer Sports Med|url=http://www.cramersportsmed.com/resources/first-aider|accessdate=14 May 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120505235217/http://www.cramersportsmed.com/resources/first-aider|archive-date=2012-05-05|dead-url=yes|df=}} An organization named the National Athletic Trainers' Association (NATA) was founded in 1938 and folded in 1944. Another NATA was founded in 1950 and still exists.{{cite book|last=Webber|first=Matt|title=Dropping the Bucket and Sponge|year=2013|publisher=Athletic Training History|location=Prescott, AZ|pages=487–505}} The first athletic training curriculum approved by NATA was in 1959 and the amount of athletic training programs began to grow throughout colleges and universities in the United States. In the early development of the major, athletic training was geared more towards prepping the student for teaching at the secondary level, emphasizing on health and physical education. This program was first introduced at an undergraduate level in 1969 to the schools of Mankato State University, Indiana State University, Lamar University, and the University of New Mexico.{{cite journal|last=Delforge|first=G.D.|author2=Behnke, R.S.|title=The History and Evolution of Athletic Training Education in the United States|journal=Journal of Athletic Training|year=1999|volume=34|issue=1|pages=53–61}} Through the years athletic training has evolved to be defined as "health care professionals who specialize in preventing, recognizing, managing, and rehabilitating injures". During the 1970s the NATA Professional Education Committee formed a list of objectives to define athletic training as a major course of study and to eliminate it as a secondary-level teaching credential. By June 1982, there were nine NATA-approved graduate athletic training education programs. On July 1, 1986, this work was used to implement athletic training as a major course of study in at least 10 colleges and universities, and to only start the development of the major in a handful of others.{{cite journal|last=Delforge|first=G.D.|author2=Behnke, R.S.|title=The History and Evolution of Athletic Training Education in the United States|journal=Journal of Athletic Training|year=1999|volume=34|issue=1|pages=53–61}} Once athletic training was recognized as an allied health profession the process of accrediting programs began. NATA's Professional Education Committee (PEC) was the first to take on this role of approving athletic training educational programs. The AMA's Committee on Allied Health Education and Accreditation (CAHEA) was given the responsibility in 1993 to develop requirements for the programs of entry-level athletic trainers. At this time all programs had to go through the CAHEA accreditation process. A year later CAHEA was broken up and replaced with the Commission on Accreditation of Allied Health Education Programs (CAAHEP), which then lead the accreditation process. In 2003 JRC-AT, Joint Review Committee on Athletic Training completely took over the process and became an independent accrediting agency like all other allied health professions had. Three years later JRC-AT officially became the Committee for Accreditation of Athletic Training Education ([https://web.archive.org/web/20110521070849/http://www.caate.net/imis15/CAATE/Accredited_Programs/Core/directory.aspx?hkey=b91f27b1-2a93-4ed1-b1e6-55cc82ac0fc3 CAATE]),{{cite web|title=Commission on Accreditation and Administration of Athletic Training Education Directory |url=http://www.caate.net/imis15/CAATE/Accredited_Programs/Core/directory.aspx?hkey=b91f27b1-2a93-4ed1-b1e6-55cc82ac0fc3 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110521070849/http://www.caate.net/imis15/CAATE/Accredited_Programs/Core/directory.aspx?hkey=b91f27b1-2a93-4ed1-b1e6-55cc82ac0fc3 |archivedate=2011-05-21 }} which is fully in charge of accrediting athletic training programs in the United States. NATA produced the NATABOC in 1969 in order to implement a certification process for the profession for an entry-level athletic trainer. In 1989, became an independent non-profit corporation and soon later changed its name to the Board of Certification ([[Board of Certification, Inc.|BOC]]).{{cite journal|last=Delforge|first=G.D.|author2=Behnke, R.S.|title=The History and Evolution of Athletic Training Education in the United States|journal=Journal of Athletic Training|year=1999|volume=34|issue=1|pages=53–61}} == Roles and responsibilities == === Scope === The [[Board of Certification, Inc.|Board of Certification]] serves as the national certifying body for athletic trainers, and its Standards of Professional Practice outline the roles and responsibilities of certified athletic trainers. Such practice standards include practice expectations such as, "The Athletic Trainer renders service or treatment under the direction of a physician."http://www.bocatc.org/images/stories/multiple_references/standardsprofessionalpractice.pdf{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Regardless of the setting, limitations and restrictions on what an athletic trainer can do and who can be treated are in large part determined by the regulatory statutes governing professional practice in individual states.Prentice, W. (2011). Principles of Athletic Training. New York: McGraw-Hill. === Referring === "In certain situations, an individual may require treatment from or consultation with a variety of both medical and nonmedical services and personnel other than the athletic trainer." It is the athletic trainer's responsibility to understand the limits of their scope of practice and recognize situations where a referral is necessary. "A number of support health services may be used including school health services, nurses, physicians, dentists, podiatrists, physician's assistants, physical therapists, strength and conditioning specialists, biomechanists, exercise physiologists, nutritionists, psychologists, massage therapists, occupational therapists, emergency medical technicians, paramedics, chiropractors, orthopedists, prosthesis, equipment personnel, referees, or social workers."Prentice, W. (2011). Principles of Athletic Training. New York: McGraw-Hill. === NATA code of ethics === "The National Athletic Trainers’ Association Code of Ethics states the principles of ethical behavior that should be followed in the practice of athletic training. It is intended to establish and maintain high standards and professionalism for the athletic training profession."http://www.nata.org/codeofethics == Employment settings == * Clinic * Hospital * Industrial/Occupational * Corporate * College/University * Two-year Institution * Secondary School * Professional Sports * Amateur/recreation/youth sports * Performing Arts * Military/Law Enforcement/Government * Health/fitness/sports/performance enhancement clinics/clubs * Independent Contractor == Education == === Undergraduate course descriptions === All courses may have prerequisites to be completed before taking further coursework. Also, those prerequisites and content of the courses will vary upon the institute and professor. The courses listed below are commonly taken to increase knowledge regarding athletic training. * Human [[Physiology]]- This course is designed to provide students with an understanding of the function and regulation of the human body and physiological integration of the organ systems to maintain homeostasis * Human [[Anatomy]]- The anatomical structures of the body will be studied in this course. Including the muscular systems, organs, respiratory, bony anatomy, veins and arteries. This course will help you to learn all components of the body and is almost always accompanied with a lab section to reinforce the lectures. * [[Exercise Physiology]]- This course investigates the acute responses and chronic adaptations of physiological functions to a wide range of physical exercise conditions, involving people of all ages and abilities. * [[Kinesiology]]- Structural and applied musculoskeletal anatomy relative to human movement and sports skill. This course concentrates on muscles, their origins, insertions, and actions. * [[Nutrition]]- This course emphasizes basic nutritional principles and concepts, their application to personal health and relationship between food and its use by the human body for energy, regulation, structure, and optimal health. Discussion of issues in nutrition during various stages of the life cycle and specific chronic diseases will be addressed. * [[Therapeutic modalities|Therapeutic Modalities]]- This is a course looks into the background for clinical application of therapeutic modalities in athletic training. Students will comprehend the underlying theories, physiological effects, indications, and contraindications of various therapeutic modalities utilized in the treatment of orthopedic injuries. * Acute Care of Injury and Illness- This course focuses on the emergency management techniques that are commonly implemented when dealing with trauma and illnesses suffered during/through sport participation. Included will be field evaluation of medical emergencies, such as cessation of breathing or circulation, shock, concussion, and spinal injury to the athlete. Students will review policies and position statements issued by the [[National Athletic Trainers' Association|NATA]], [[NCAA]], [[American College of Sports Medicine|ACSM]], [[Association of American Physicians|AAP]], and [[American Medical Association|AMA]] regarding prevention, evaluation, and management of acute athletic injuries and illnesses. * Physical Examination of the Lower Extremities- Intense in-depth study of the lower extremities including physical examinations, injury recognition, treatment, taping, bracing, and care. Laboratory experiences emphasize the methods and techniques in evaluating lower extremity injuries/conditions.http://catalog.whitworth.edu/undergraduate/healthsciences/healthsciences.pdf === Undergraduate athletic training programs === The Commission on Accreditation of Athletic Training Education (CAATE) [http://www.caate.net website] provides a list of all the [https://web.archive.org/web/20110521070849/http://www.caate.net/imis15/CAATE/Accredited_Programs/Core/directory.aspx?hkey=b91f27b1-2a93-4ed1-b1e6-55cc82ac0fc3 accredited programs] in the United States.{{cite web|title=Commission on Accreditation and Administration of Athletic Training Education|url=http://www.uncg.edu/kin/atep/applicationprocess.html|accessdate=10 May 2012}} It provides you with the name of the college, who to contact, and a link to the institution's website. An Undergraduate Athletic Training degree can only be received at an accredited school for athletic training. === Entry-level masters programs === Although the majority of athletic trainers receive a bachelor's degree in athletic training before taking the Board of Certification Exam (BOC), it is not the only way to receive an education in athletic training. An entry-level masters program is a two-year program that covers the same material as an undergraduate athletic training degree. Common prerequisite classes are human anatomy, human physiology, kinesiology, biomechanics, exercise physiology, nutrition, and personal health along with a certain number of observation hours completed under the supervision of a certified athletic trainer (ATC).{{cite web|title=Commission on Accreditation and Administration of Athletic Training Education|url=http://www.uncg.edu/kin/atep/applicationprocess.html|accessdate=10 May 2012}} Prerequisites can vary by institution so be sure to research the prerequisites for your institutions of interest. There are 26 accredited entry level masters programs in the U.S.A. See below for a link to a list of these institutions. === Graduate school in athletic training and related fields === There are approximately 15 accredited athletic training masters programs.{{cite book|last=Prentice|first=William|title=Principles of Athletic Training: A Competency-Based Approach|year=2011|publisher=McGraw Hill|location=New York, NY|isbn=9780073523736|pages=29}} These programs consist of students who are already certified athletic trainers that want to advance their academic and clinical experience.{{cite book|last=Prentice|first=William|title=Principles of Athletic Training: A Competency-Based Approach|year=2011|publisher=McGraw Hill|location=New York, NY|isbn=9780073523736|pages=29}} These are two-year programs which culminate with a Master of Science degree (M.S.) in athletic training. Graduate programs in athletic training are not always specifically in athletic training, but in a related field. Some of these fields may include, but are not limited to, kinesiology, biomechanics, sports management, sport and exercise psychology, exercise physiology, health promotion, etc.{{cite web|title=Athletic Training Graduate Programs|url=https://www.gradschools.com/programs/physical-occupational-therapy/athletic-training|accessdate=10 May 2012}} These programs are also two years in length. While enrolled in one of these programs, the athletic trainer may gain clinical experience and receive a stipend through a make some money by obtaining a graduate assistantship. === Link to schools === *[http://www.caate.net/imis15/CAATE/Accredited_Programs/Core/directory.aspx?hkey=b91f27b1-2a93-4ed1-b1e6-%2055cc82ac0fc3 Entry Level Masters Programs in the U.S.A]{{Dead link|date=August 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}.{{cite web|title=Commission on Accreditation and Administration of Athletic Training Education |url=http://www.caate.net/imis15/CAATE/Accredited_Programs/Core/directory.aspx?hkey=b91f27b1-2a93-4ed1-b1e6-55cc82ac0fc3 |accessdate=10 May 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110521070849/http://www.caate.net/imis15/CAATE/Accredited_Programs/Core/directory.aspx?hkey=b91f27b1-2a93-4ed1-b1e6-55cc82ac0fc3 |archivedate=21 May 2011 }} *[http://www.nata.org/education/educational-programs/accredited-programs Post-professional Programs in Athletic Training]{{cite web|title=National Athletic Trainers’ Association: Accredited-Programs|url=http://www.nata.org/education/educational-programs/accredited-programs|accessdate=10 May 2012}} === Graduate assistant position === A graduate assistant athletic trainer position is a position in which a graduate athletic training student is able to work as an assistant athletic trainer while taking graduate courses. Graduate assistant athletic trainers are responsible for providing the medical coverage of select teams at the institution where they are working. Responsibilities may vary, but include administering daily medical coverage for selected intercollegiate athletic teams (practice/event); traveling with the assigned team, evaluation and documentation of athletic injuries, administrative responsibilities, serve as Approved Clinical Instructor (ACI) or Clinical Instructor (CI) in a CAATE – accredited ATEP, and other duties as assigned by the head athletic trainer.{{cite web|title=National Athletic Trainers’ Association Career Center|url=http://jobs.nata.org/jobs/4697707/?ref=1|accessdate=11 May 2012}}{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Other responsibilities may include working at a high school, clinic, teaching, or doing research. Graduate assistant positions are generally about 10-month appointments that are renewable after the first year, and may include additional summer work. Visit the National Athletic Trainers’ Association Career Center for job postings.{{cite web|title=National Athletic Trainers' Association Career Center|url=http://www.nata.org/career-center|accessdate=11 May 2012}} === Accredited programs === Athletic Training programs are evaluated by CAATE to ensure that they follow the standards for Entry-Level Athletic Training Programs. Evaluations may take place every three to seven years depending on the results of the last visit. Successfully completing the CAATE accredited education program is a part of the criteria that determines a candidate's eligibility for the Board of Certification (BOC) examination.{{cite web|title=Commission on Accreditation of Athletic Training Education: Overview of the Commission|url=http://www.caate.net/imis15/CAATE/About/CAATE/About.aspx?hkey=1b198b36-7205-4b7f-9447-abd3800a3264|accessdate=11 May 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120525154253/http://www.caate.net/imis15/CAATE/About/CAATE/About.aspx?hkey=1b198b36-7205-4b7f-9447-abd3800a3264|archivedate=25 May 2012|df=}}{{cite web|title=Board of Certification|url=http://www.bocatc.org/|accessdate=11 May 2012}} == Organizations == "The National Athletic Trainers’ Association (NATA) is the professional membership association for certified athletic trainers and others who support the athletic training profession. Founded in 1950, the NATA has grown to more than 35,000 members worldwide today. The majority of certified athletic trainers choose to be members of the NATA – to support their profession, and to receive a broad array of membership benefits. By joining forces as a group, NATA members can accomplish more for the athletic training profession than they can individually".{{cite web|title=NATA|url=http://www.nata.org/aboutNATA|accessdate=2013-02-25}} Before the formation of NATA, athletic trainers occupied a somewhat insecure place in the athletic program. Since that time, as a direct result of the standards and ethics established by NATA, there has been considerable professional advancement.Prentice, W. (2011). Principles of Athletic Training. New York: McGraw-Hill. Every year NATA works on behalf of all athletic trainers to enhance health care for both athletic trainers and those who receive care. NATA is the professional organization for Athletic trainers across the nation. Each region of the USA has their own district under NATA but within their area, they have their own agendas and board members. Each district also has a director that serves on the NATA Board of Directors.{{cite web|title=NATA|url=http://www.nata.org/aboutNATA|accessdate=2012-05-10}} [[National Athletic Trainers' Association#NATA Districts|There are 10 districts]]. Every state has their own state athletic training association that acts similar to the district associations as they have their own board members. The state associations answer to the district associations and the National Athletic Trainers’ Association. Links to the state associations can be found through the regional websites.{{cite web|title=NATA|url=http://www.nata.org/aboutNATA|accessdate=2012-05-10}} == Current topics == Due to the physicality of athletics and the campaign for healthy well-being, there are issues that become hot topics in the media. Athletic trainers have to continually be aware of changes in laws, position statements of the National Athletic Trainers Association, and institutional policies.{{cite web|title=NATA Press Room|url=http://www.nata.org/press-room/news-releases|publisher=NATA|accessdate=2012-05-10|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120814102739/http://www.nata.org/press-room/news-releases|archivedate=2012-08-14|df=}} Current hot topics and topics to keep an eye on include: * [https://web.archive.org/web/20120814102739/http://www.nata.org/press-room/news-releases NATA Press Room] * [http://www.nata.org/statements|publisher=NATA Concussion laws, position statements, and policies.]{{cite web|title=NATA Statements|url=http://www.nata.org/statements|publisher=NATA|accessdate=2012-05-10|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120509081411/http://www.nata.org/statements|archivedate=2012-05-09|df=}} * Youth Sports Legislation * Guidelines in Prevention of Chronic Overuse Injury in Pediatric Patients * [http://www.nata.org/sites/default/files/using-certified-athletic-trainers-as-physician-extenders.pdf Athletic Trainers as Physician Extenders]{{cite web|title=Athletic Trainers as Physician Extenders|url=http://www.nata.org/sites/default/files/using-certified-athletic-trainers-as-physician-extenders.pdf|publisher=NATA|accessdate=2012-05-10|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130203034504/http://www.nata.org/sites/default/files/using-certified-athletic-trainers-as-physician-extenders.pdf|archivedate=2013-02-03|df=}} * Education on Public Safety in the Workplace * [http://www.nata.org/sites/default/files/atc-as-partner.pdf Certified Athletic Trainer as a partner in the Athletic Department]{{cite web|title=Certified Athletic Trainers as a partner in the Athletic Department|url=http://www.nata.org/sites/default/files/atc-as-partner.pdf|publisher=NATA|accessdate=2008-08-01}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== *{{Commonscat-inline}} {{Allied health professions}} [[Category:Athletic training| ]] [[Category:Sports medicine]] [[Category:Rehabilitation medicine]] [[Category:Physical exercise]] [[Category:Manual therapy]] [[Category:Massage therapy]]

Recent: {{Season list one year|prefix=Belgium at the_|suffix=_UCI Track Cycling World Championships}} | previous = | next = }} '''[[Belgium]]''' competed at the '''[[2015 UCI Track Cycling World Championships]]''' in [[Saint-Quentin-en-Yvelines]] at the [[Vélodrome de Saint-Quentin-en-Yvelines]] from 18–22 February 2015. A team of 10 cyclists (3 women, 7 men) was announced to represent the country in the event.{{cite web |title=Entry list women |url= http://www.uci.ch/mm/Document/News/NewsGeneral/16/85/16/20150212_SQEY_WE_EntryListUCIwebsite_English.PDF |work=UCI |date=12 February 2015}}{{cite web |title=Entry list men |url= http://www.uci.ch/mm/Document/News/NewsGeneral/16/85/15/20150212_SQEY_ME_EntryListUCIwebsite_English.PDF |work=UCI |date=12 February 2015}} ==Results== ===Men=== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- !Name !Event !Result !Rank |- | [[Dominique Cornu]] || [[2015 UCI Track Cycling World Championships – Men's individual pursuit|Men's individual pursuit]] ||4:26.032||align=center|11 |- | [[Otto Vergaerde]] || [[2015 UCI Track Cycling World Championships – Men's scratch|Men's scratch]] ||{{n/a}}||align=center|11 |- | [[Moreno De Pauw]] || [[2015 UCI Track Cycling World Championships – Men's points race|Men's points race]] ||10 points||align=center|12 |- | [[Jasper De Buyst]] || [[2015 UCI Track Cycling World Championships – Men's omnium|Men's omnium]] ||178 points||align=center|4 |- | [[Jasper De Buyst]]
[[Otto Vergaerde]] || [[2015 UCI Track Cycling World Championships – Men's madison|Men's madison]] ||15 points||align=center|{{brca}} |- | [[Jasper De Buyst]]

{{for|the Vietnam War protest in the United States|Tinker v. Des Moines Independent Community School District}} {{good article}} {{Use British English| date=January 2017}} {{Use dmy dates| date=January 2017}} {{Infobox event | title = Black armband protest | image = | image_size = | image_alt = | caption = | duration = [[2003 Cricket World Cup]] | venue = [[Harare Sports Club]], Harare | cause = Protest about democracy in Zimbabwe | participants = [[Andy Flower]], [[Henry Olonga]] }}
The '''black armband protest''' was made by [[Zimbabwe]]an cricketers [[Andy Flower]] and [[Henry Olonga]] during the [[2003 Cricket World Cup]]. The pair decided to wear [[black armband]]s to "mourn the death of democracy in Zimbabwe". The protest received condemnation from senior Zimbabwean political figures, and also some senior Zimbabwean cricket figures, but was praised by the international media. The [[International Cricket Council]] deemed that Flower and Olonga had taken a political action, but refused to charge the pair with an offence. Their initial protest was during Zimbabwe's first match of the tournament in [[Harare]], and the pair wore armbands to protest at all of the matches. As a result of the protest, Flower and Olonga were forced to leave Zimbabwe, and both men later settled in the United Kingdom.
== Background == [[File:Andy Flower.png|thumb|200px|[[Andy Flower]], one of the players involved in the protest.]]
The [[2003 Cricket World Cup]] was awarded to [[South Africa national cricket team|South Africa]], however they decided to award six of the group stage matches to Zimbabwe, and two to [[Kenya national cricket team|Kenya]].<ref name="Social 2003 WC">{{cite book|url= https://books.google.com/books?id=sQncAAAAQBAJ&pg=PA47&lpg=PA47&dq=south+africa+2003+cricket+world+cup+hosts&source=bl&ots=QRSORauM8W&sig=6DN2WXgZpU6TCjvmyWyMZqHjRBk&hl=en&sa=X&ei=xet1VYa8LeXZ7gbl0oGACA&ved=0CFAQ6AEwCDgK#v=onepage&q=south%20africa%202003%20cricket%20world%20cup%20hosts&f=false| title= Forty Years of Sport and Social Change, 1968–2008: "To Remember is to Resist"| last1= Field |first1= Russell|last2= Kidd| first2= Bruce| pages= 47–53| date=2010| accessdate=8 June 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url= http://topendsports.com/events/cricket-world-cup/hosts/2003-southern-africa/index.htm| title= South Africa, Zimbabwe & Kenya, 2003|publisher= Top End Sports|accessdate=8 June 2015}}</ref> Due to security concerns in Zimbabwe, the British and Australian governments both advised their players against travelling to Zimbabwe.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.island.lk/2003/02/06/sports01.html| title= England, Australia want Zimbabwe switch|publisher=Reuters|date= 4 February 2003|accessdate=8 June 2015}}</ref> In the end, England forfeited their match, whilst Australia played and won their match.<ref name="Cricinfo World Cup No. 8"/><ref>{{cite web|url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport3/cwc2003/hi/newsid_2760000/newsid_2765300/2765355.stm| title= England forfeit Zimbabwe points| publisher=BBC Sport|date= 15 February 2003|accessdate=8 June 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.espncricinfo.com/ci/engine/match/65259.html|title= ICC World Cup, 27th Match: Zimbabwe v Australia at Bulawayo, Feb 24, 2003| publisher= ESPN Cricinfo|accessdate=8 June 2015}}</ref>
The idea of a protest was started when Andy Flower was taken by a friend, Nigel Huff, to see a farm impacted by the government's land reforms.<ref name="BBC">{{cite web|url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/cricket/21359274| title=Andy Flower & Henry Olonga: the 'death of democracy' remembered|publisher=BBC Sport| date=7 February 2013|accessdate=9 June 2015}}</ref> In 2000, [[Robert Mugabe]] and the Zimbabwean government had begun a plan of land reforms for redistribution of 3,000 farms,<ref name="Land">{{cite web| url= https://books.google.com/books?id=kYSDceThCesC&pg=PA11&lpg=PA11&dq=zimbabwe+seize+white+farms+2002&source=bl&ots=BvOsZnvy46&sig=2u0dPiCTpizSYAkkP5y9xUGKwy0&hl=en&sa=X&ei=PuB1VYfLDsLB7AbC9YH4CQ&ved=0CDYQ6AEwBDgK#v=onepage&q=zimbabwe%20seize%20white%20farms%202002&f=false| title= Zimbabwe: Fast Track Land Reform in Zimbabwe| last1= Manby | first1= Bronwen | date=2002 |pages= 11–12|accessdate=8 June 2015}}</ref> and began compulsorily seizing land from white farmers, with forced evictions and arrests on the basis of "illegally occupying their land".<ref>{{cite web|url= https://www.nytimes.com/2002/08/17/world/zimbabwe-starts-arresting-white-farmers-defying-eviction.html|title= Zimbabwe Starts Arresting White Farmers Defying Eviction|publisher= The New York Times|date= 17 August 2002|accessdate=8 June 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2002/jun/26/zimbabwe |title= New legal battle to keep Zimbabwe farming|publisher= The Guardian|date= 26 June 2002|accessdate=8 June 2015}}</ref> By 2002, it was estimated that around 80% of the 4,500 farms that had been white-owned had been forcibly seized.<ref>{{cite book|url= https://books.google.com/books?id=rX7sqS3YR_AC&pg=PA211&lpg=PA211&dq=zimbabwe+seize+white+farms+2002&source=bl&ots=Bo2OmfeolY&sig=d5D5vwNsG7AJAoKi-N9wX6B3VJo&hl=en&sa=X&ei=PuB1VYfLDsLB7AbC9YH4CQ&ved=0CEUQ6AEwCDgK#v=onepage&q=zimbabwe%20seize%20white%20farms%202002&f=false|title= The Postcolonial State in Africa: Fifty Years of Independence, 1960–2010|last1= Young| first1= Crawford|date=2012|page=211|accessdate=8 June 2015}}</ref> Another related issue was human rights abuses and violence, particularly against political opponents in the leadup to the [[Zimbabwean presidential election, 2002|2002 Zimbabwe presidential election]]. The EU had imposed sanctions on Zimbabwe's ruling elite,<ref>{{cite web|url= https://www.theguardian.com/world/2002/feb/18/zimbabwe| title= EU imposes sanctions on Zimbabwe|publisher=The Guardian|date=18 February 2002|accessdate=8 June 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/africa/1827827.stm|title= EU agrees Zimbabwe sanctions|publisher=BBC News|date=18 February 2002|accessdate=8 June 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url= https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/africaandindianocean/zimbabwe/1385370/EU-imposes-sanctions-on-Mugabe-inner-circle.html| title= EU imposes sanctions on Mugabe inner circle|publisher=The Telegraph|date=19 February 2002|accessdate=8 June 2015}}</ref> which, as of 2017, are still in place.<ref>{{cite web| url= https://www.reuters.com/article/2015/02/03/us-africa-mugabe-eu-idUSKBN0L72DM20150203|title= Zimbabwe's Mugabe may be allowed in to EU in new role|publisher=Reuters|date=3 February 2015|accessdate=8 June 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.enca.com/africa/southern-africa/eu-court-dismisses-zimbabwe-sanctions-appeal|title= EU court dismisses Zimbabwe sanctions appeal| publisher=Enca|date=22 April 2015|accessdate=8 June 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite book| url= https://books.google.com/books?id=ytuqCwAAQBAJ&dq=eu+sanctions+on+zimbabwe%27s+ruling+elite&source=gbs_navlinks_s| title= The Success of Sanctions: Lessons Learned from the EU Experience| last=Giumelli| first=Francesco| publisher=[[Routledge]]| pages=106–116| date=3 March 2016| access-date=22 April 2017}}</ref> Flower was particularly appalled by the torture of [[Member of parliament#Zimbabwe|Zimbabwean MP]] Job Sikhala.<ref name="Cricket County">{{cite web|url= http://www.cricketcountry.com/articles/icc-world-cup-2003-andy-flower-and-henry-olonga-don-black-armbands-246948| title= ICC World Cup 2003: Andy Flower and Henry Olonga don black armbands|publisher= Cricket County|date=9 February 2015|accessdate=9 June 2015}}</ref>
== The protest == [[File:David Coltart.JPG|thumb|right|200px|[[David Coltart]], who suggested the wearing of black armbands.]]
=== Planning ===
After Flower had decided to protest, he decided that he wanted Olonga to partner him in the protest, as "one white Zimbabwean and one black one operating together gave the message the most eloquent balance."<ref name="BBC" /> Olonga was the first black, and the youngest ever, cricketer to play for Zimbabwe.<ref name="CNN">{{cite web|url= http://edition.cnn.com/2010/WORLD/africa/08/31/henry.olonga.zimbabwe/| title= Henry Olonga, Zimbabwe's cricketing rebel |publisher=CNN|date= 7 September 2010|accessdate=9 June 2015}}</ref><ref name="Independent">{{cite web| url= https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/profiles/henry-olonga-he-has-a-love-for-zimbabwe-even-now-but-while-mugabe-is-alive-he-knows-he-cant-return-2034849.html|title= Henry Olonga: He has a love for Zimbabwe even now. But while Mugabe is alive, he knows he can't return|publisher= The Independent| date=25 July 2010|accessdate=9 June 2015}}</ref> They met up in a news café in [[Harare]] to plan the protest, originally considering withdrawing from the [[2003 Cricket World Cup|World Cup]], but later deciding to protest instead.<ref name="Cricket County" /><ref name="Principles">{{cite web|url= http://www.espncricinfo.com/magazine/content/story/292618.html| title= Standing up for their principles| publisher= ESPN Cricinfo|date=27 April 2007|accessdate=9 June 2015}}</ref> The pair spoke with lawyer [[David Coltart]], a founding member of the [[Movement for Democratic Change – Tsvangirai|Movement for Democratic Change]]. Coltart suggested wearing black armbands, and helped word the statement in a non-incriminating way.<ref name="Cricinfo World Cup No. 8"/><ref name="Guardian Olonga">{{cite web|url= https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2003/dec/16/cricket1| title= How I risked it all with a black armband|publisher=The Guardian|date= 16 December 2003| accessdate=12 June 2015}}</ref><ref name="Standard">{{cite web|url= https://www.standard.co.uk/sport/olonga-a-hero-in-exile-7241014.html| title= Olonga: A hero in exile| publisher=London Evening Standard| date=28 February 2007|accessdate=9 June 2015}}</ref>
=== The protest itself === The match in question was between Zimbabwe and Namibia on 10 March 2003.<ref name="Cricket County" /> The match was being played at the [[Harare Sports Club]], and was the first World Cup match hosted in Zimbabwe.<ref name="Wisden">{{cite book|url= https://books.google.com/books?id=ne8EAQAAQBAJ&pg=PA565&dq=cricket+black+armband+protest&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CFIQ6AEwCWoVChMIyc_arJ6LxgIVrhfbCh0ApQCn#v=onepage&q=cricket%20black%20armband%20protest&f=false| title= The Essential Wisden: An Anthology of 150 Years of Wisden Cricketers' Almanack| last1=Stern |first1= John |last2= Williams| first2=Marcus|date=2013|page=565|accessdate=13 June 2015}}</ref><ref name="Cricinfo World Cup No. 8"/> Prior to the protest, the only other Zimbabwean player who knew about the protest was Andy's brother Grant.<ref name="Cricket County" /><ref name="Cricinfo Great Moments">{{cite web|url=http://www.espncricinfo.com/wctimeline/content/current/story/281633.html|title= Zimbabwe's black armband protest|publisher=ESPN Cricinfo|accessdate=13 June 2015}}</ref> In the end, the pair did not have any black armbands, and so used black insulating tape instead.<ref name=Times>{{cite news| url= https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/rebel-henry-olonga-calls-for-end-to-zimbabwe-exile-from-test-arena-nm0d35f2qr2| title= Rebel Henry Olonga calls for end to Zimbabwe exile from Test arena| last=Broadbent| first=Rick| work=[[The Times]]| subscription=y| date=8 August 2010| accessdate=22 April 2017}}</ref><ref name=Independent2004>{{cite news| url= https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/cricket/henry-olonga-a-year-after-his-heroic-protest-the-rebel-still-walks-the-high-ground-71280.html| title= Henry Olonga: A year after his heroic protest, the rebel still walks the high ground|last=Viner| first=Brian| work=[[The Independent]]| date=28 February 2004| accessdate=22 April 2017}}</ref> Shortly before the match, they delivered their 450-word statement to the press. The statement later became commonly known as "mourning the death of democracy in Zimbabwe":<ref name="BBC" /><ref name="Cricinfo Great Moments" /><ref name="Sky">{{cite web|url= http://www1.skysports.com/cricket/news/12172/9634354/world-cup-controversies-warne-is-sent-home-and-freddie-is-sent-into-the-sea| title= World Cup controversies: Protests and Pedalos – Zimbabwe's stand and Freddie's fall...|publisher=Sky Sports|date=6 February 2015|accessdate=13 June 2015}}</ref> {{quote|In all the circumstances, we have decided that we will each wear a black armband for the duration of the World Cup. In doing so we are mourning the death of democracy in our beloved Zimbabwe. In doing so we are making a silent plea to those responsible to stop the abuse of human rights in Zimbabwe. In doing so, we pray that our small action may help to restore sanity and dignity to our nation.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.espncricinfo.com/ci/content/story/126517.html|title=Statement of Andrew Flower and Henry Olonga|publisher=ESPN Cricinfo|date=10 February 2003|accessdate=13 June 2015}}</ref>}}
In the match, Zimbabwe batted first, and the public at the ground were not aware of the protest until the 22nd over, when Flower came out to bat wearing a black armband.<ref name="Cricinfo Great Moments" /> Olonga was also seen wearing a black armband on the Zimbabwe team balcony.<ref name="Cricket County" /> The crowd of 4,000 at the ground were supportive of the protest, and a number of them made their own black armbands during the match.<ref name="Social 2003 WC"/> In the match itself, Flower scored 39, as Zimbabwe reached 340/2, and Olonga took 0/8 in 3 overs, as Zimbabwe won a rain-affected match by 86 runs ([[Duckworth-Lewis method|D/L method]]).<ref name="Wisden" /><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.espncricinfo.com/ci/engine/current/match/65236.html|title=ICC World Cup, 2nd Match: Zimbabwe v Namibia at Harare, Feb 10, 2003|publisher=ESPN Cricinfo|accessdate=26 June 2015}}</ref>
== Reactions == [[File:Nasser Hussain.JPG|thumb|right|Former England captain [[Nasser Hussain]], who said Flower and Olonga "have proved to be great men by what they have done."]]
After the match, one man was arrested for wearing a black armband.<ref name="Guardian">{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2003/feb/11/cricketworldcup2003.cricketworldcup3|title= Olonga risks his career with political protest| publisher=The Guardian|date=11 February 2015|accessdate=26 June 2015}}</ref> During Zimbabwe's next{{efn|name=Ex|Excluding the walkover against England}} group stage match against India, nearly 200 spectators wore black armbands, to support the protest.<ref name="Social 2003 WC" />
Inside Zimbabwe, the reaction was hostile to the players. Zimbabwe's [[Minister of Information]], [[Jonathan Moyo]], called Olonga an "Uncle Tom" who had "a black skin and a white mask".<ref name="Cricinfo Great Moments" /><ref name="Cricinfo World Cup No. 8">{{cite news | url=http://www.espncricinfo.com/wctimeline/content/current/story/825253.html | title=Olonga and Flower make a stand | work=Cricinfo | date=2 February 2015 | accessdate=28 February 2016 | author=Brickhill, Liam}}</ref> [[Zanu PF]] information secretary [[Nathan Shamuyarira]] claimed they were forced into it by the British media, and "No true Zimbabwean would have joined in," but "Olonga is not a Zimbabwean, he is a Zambian".<ref name="BBC" /><ref name="Guardian events" /> Olonga was charged with treason, an offence punishable by death.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.iol.co.za/sport/cricket/olonga-sought-for-treason-1.103157#.VY6CM_lViko| title= Olonga 'sought for treason'| publisher=IOL Sport|date=17 March 2003|accessdate=27 June 2015}}</ref> MDC leader [[Morgan Tsvangirai]] released a statement in support of the protest. He was charged with treason, although the charge was later dropped.<ref name=BBC2003/> Givemore Makoni, the President of [[Takashinga Cricket Club]] where Olonga played said "It is disgraceful what Henry Olonga and Andy Flower have done. Taking politics on to the playing field is a thing the International Cricket Council and all sports organisations have been trying to avoid," and that "by taking politics on to the field and bringing the game into disrepute Henry appears to have breached Takashinga's code of conduct".<ref name="Guardian" /> Olonga was immediately suspended and later sacked by Takashinga Cricket Club.<ref name=BBC2003>{{cite news| url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/africa/2748899.stm| title= Brave cricketers risk Mugabe's wrath| last=Winter| first=Joseph| work=[[BBC News]]| date=11 March 2003| accessdate=22 April 2017}}</ref><ref name="Guardian events">{{cite web|url= https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2003/mar/17/cricketworldcup2003.cricketworldcup|title= 'I was a cricketer. Now it's time for music'| publisher= The Guardian|date= 17 March 2003|accessdate=26 June 2015}}</ref> Stephen Mandongo, the President of the [[Zimbabwe Cricket Union]] also condemned the protest, saying "What Flower and Olonga did is very wrong. They have jeopardised our reputation when given this once in a lifetime chance to host the World Cup ... It would be wrong if they wore black armbands again."<ref name="Social 2003 WC" /> They referred the matter to the [[International Cricket Council]], who deemed that they had taken a political action, but refused to charge them with a formal offence. Instead, they released a statement reiterating the apolitical nature of the organisation, and asked the players not to wear black armbands for the rest of the tournament, with the threat of more serious punishment if they continued to wear them.<ref name="Social 2003 WC" /><ref name="Guardian events" />
The international reaction to the protest was favourable. [[The Times]] sports correspondent called it a "powerful blow for sanity, decency and democracy", whilst [[The Daily Telegraph]]'s [[Donald Trelford]] praised the players and criticised the [[International Cricket Council|ICC]] and [[England and Wales Cricket Board|ECB]], saying the players "shine out like diamonds in a pile of mud".<ref name="Cricinfo Great Moments" /> Cricket writer [[Tim de Lisle]] praised the pair, saying that "Together they were responsible for a shining moment in the game's history ... Two strips of black tape, more potent than any logo, breathed life back into the game's battered spirit."<ref name="Social 2003 WC" /> [[England national cricket team|England]] captain [[Nasser Hussain]] said that Flower and Olonga "have proved to be great men by what they have done."<ref name="Guardian events" /> As a result of the protest, Olonga's girlfriend broke up with him, and he received numerous threatening emails and death threats.<ref name="BBC" /><ref name="Principles" />
== Aftermath == [[File:Electrical-tape black.jpg|thumb|200px|Insulating tape was used instead of black armbands in the protest.]]
Zimbabwe won their next match against [[England national cricket team|England]] on a walkover, and also beat the [[Netherlands cricket team|Netherlands]], and had a no-result in their final group match against [[Pakistan national cricket team|Pakistan]], which allowed them to qualify for the Super 6 stage of the competition.<ref name="Wisden" /><ref name="WC 2003 Results">{{cite web|url= http://www.espncricinfo.com/ci/content/series/61124.html?template=fixtures| title= Fixtures: Zimbabwe| publisher=ESPN Cricinfo|accessdate=27 June 2015}}</ref> They were eliminated in this stage,<ref name="Wisden" /><ref name="WC 2003 Results" /> however this allowed both players to leave Zimbabwe for South Africa.<ref name="Guardian Olonga" />
Olonga was dropped for 6 matches,{{efn|Including the walkover against England}} with no reason given – some have speculated that he was dropped as a result of the protest, whilst other suggest it was due to poor form.<ref name="Cricket County" /> Flower on the other hand was considered "undroppable".<ref name="Cricket County" /><ref name="Principles" /> To comply with the ICC warning not to wear black armbands, during their next{{efn|name=Ex|Excluding the walkover against England}} group match, Flower and [[Glossary of cricket terms#T|twelfth-man]] Olonga both wore black wristbands, and in subsequent matches, Flower wore white armbands.<ref name="Cricket County" /> Olonga's only subsequent appearance for Zimbabwe was in their match against Kenya.<ref name="WC 2003 Results" />
After their final Super Six match, Olonga immediately announced his retirement from international cricket, after 30 Test matches and 50 ODIs.<ref name="Principles" /><ref name="Standard" /> Flower had already previously announced his retirement from international cricket, and had signed for [[Essex County Cricket Club|Essex]], and [[South Australia cricket team|South Australia]].<ref name="Social 2003 WC" /><ref>{{cite web|url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport3/cwc2003/low/newsid_2860000/newsid_2863100/2863151.stm| title= Flower to play in Australia|publisher=BBC Sport|date= 19 March 2003|accessdate=27 June 2015}}</ref> Olonga, had not planned what to do after the protest, as he "had in my own naivety thought that I could carry on in Zimbabwe – maybe my career would come to an end but I could still live there."<ref name="BBC" /> In the end, he was kicked off the team bus,<ref name="Cricket County" /><ref name="Cricinfo Great Moments" /> and travelled to [[Johannesburg]], where he stayed for a month, before being granted a work permit to play for Lashings Cricket Club in England.<ref name="Independent" /><ref name=Independent2004/><ref name="Guardian Olonga" /> He was subsequently granted asylum in the United Kingdom.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.abc.net.au/news/2003-10-09/olonga-granted-extended-refuge-in-britain/1490854| title= Olonga granted extended refuge in Britain|publisher=ABC|date=9 October 2003|accessdate=27 June 2015}}</ref> Neither player has since returned to Zimbabwe.<ref name="BBC" /><ref name="Guardian Olonga" />
== Legacy ==
Both players were awarded an Honorary Life Membership of the [[Marylebone Cricket Club]], an honour usually only given to players who have retired from [[first-class cricket]].<ref name="Cricket County" /> In 2013, the [[BBC]] recorded a special radio programme commemorating 10 years of the protest.<ref name="BBC" />

{{short description|Deadly explosions during the 2013 Boston Marathon, and subsequent shooting and manhunt}} {{Redirect|Boston bomber|the Douglas Boston bomber aircraft|Douglas A-20 Havoc}} {{pp-move|small=yes}} {{Use mdy dates|date=April 2015}} {{Infobox civilian attack | title=Boston Marathon bombing | partof=[[Terrorism in the United States]] | image=1st Boston Marathon blast seen from 2nd floor and a half block away.jpg | image_upright=1.15 | alt= | caption=Moments after the first explosion | map= | map_size= | map_alt= | map_caption= | location=671–673 and 755 Boylston Street, [[Boston]], [[Massachusetts]] | target=[[Boston Marathon]] | date={{start date|2013|4|15}} | time={{Nowrap|2:49 p.m.}} | timezone=[[Eastern Time Zone|EDT]] | type=[[Improvised explosive device|Bombings]] | fatalities= 3 | injuries= {{abbr|≈|approximately}} 264 | victim= | perp= | perpetrators= * [[Dzhokhar Tsarnaev]] (sentenced to death) * [[Tamerlan Tsarnaev]] (deceased) | perpetrator= | perps= | susperp= | weapons= Two [[pressure cooker bomb]]s | numparts= | numpart= | dfens= | dfen= | footage= | motive= Retribution for U.S. military action in Afghanistan and Iraq }} During the annual [[Boston Marathon]] on April 15, 2013, two homemade pressure cooker bombs detonated 12 seconds and {{convert|210|yd|m}} apart at 2:49 p.m., near the finish line of the race, killing three people and injuring several hundred others, including 16 who lost limbs. Three days later, the [[Federal Bureau of Investigation]] (FBI) released images of two suspects, who were later identified as [[Kyrgyzstan|Kyrgyz]]-American brothers [[Dzhokhar Tsarnaev]] and [[Tamerlan Tsarnaev]]. They killed an [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology Police Department#Shooting by Boston Marathon bombing suspects|MIT policeman]], kidnapped a man in his car, and had a shootout with the police in nearby [[Watertown, Massachusetts|Watertown]], during which two officers were severely injured, one of whom died a year later. Tamerlan was shot several times, and his brother ran him over while escaping in the stolen car; Tamerlan died soon after. An unprecedented [[Manhunt (law enforcement)|manhunt]] for Dzhokhar ensued on April 19, with thousands of law enforcement officers searching a 20-block area of Watertown; residents of Watertown and surrounding communities were asked to stay indoors, and the transportation system and most businesses and public places closed. Around 6:00 p.m., a Watertown resident discovered Dzhokhar hiding in a boat in his backyard."Two unnamed officials say Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, 19, did not have a gun when he was captured Friday in a Watertown, Mass. backyard. Boston Police Commissioner Ed Davis said earlier that shots were fired from inside the boat." The Associated Press Wednesday, April 24, 2013, 8:42 PM. He was shot and wounded by police before being taken into custody. During questioning, Dzhokhar said that he and his brother were motivated by extremist [[Islamism|Islamist]] beliefs and the [[Iraq War|wars in Iraq]] and [[War in Afghanistan (2001–present)|Afghanistan]], that they were self-radicalized and unconnected to any outside terrorist groups, and that he was following his brother's lead. He said they learned to build explosive devices from an [[Inspire (magazine)|online magazine]] of the [[al-Qaeda]] affiliate in [[Yemen]]. He also said they had intended to travel to [[New York City]] to bomb [[Times Square]]. On April 8, 2015, he was convicted of 30 charges, including use of a [[Weapon of mass destruction#Criminal (civilian)|weapon of mass destruction]] and malicious destruction of property resulting in death.{{cite news|title=Dzhokhar Tsarnaev: Boston Marathon bomber found guilty|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-32225787|accessdate=April 8, 2015|publisher=BBC News|date=April 8, 2015}} Two months later, he was sentenced to death.{{Cite news|url=http://www.ibtimes.com/what-happened-dzhokhar-tsarnaev-update-boston-marathon-bomber-sentenced-death-2526052|title=What Happened To Dzhokhar Tsarnaev? Update On Boston Marathon Bomber Sentenced To Death|date=2017-04-16|work=International Business Times|access-date=2018-03-12}} {{toclimit|3}} == Bombing == [[File:2013 Boston Marathon bombings map.png|thumb|left|The blasts (red) occurred along the marathon course (dark blue), the first nearer the finish line than the second.]] {{multiple image|caption_align=center | header_align=center | direction=vertical | width = 220 | image1 = Boston Marathon explosions (8652877581).jpg | image2 = 2013 Boston Marathon aftermath people.jpg | image3 = Boston Marathon explosions (8652971845).jpg | footer = }} The [[2013 Boston Marathon|117th annual Boston Marathon]] was run on [[Patriots' Day]], April 15, 2013. At {{Nowrap |2:49 p.m. [[Eastern Time Zone|EDT]]}} {{Nowrap|(18:49 [[Coordinated Universal Time|UTC]])}}, two bombs detonated about {{convert|210|yd|m}} apart at the finish line on Boylston Street near [[Copley Square]]. The first exploded outside [[Marathon Sports (retailer)|Marathon Sports]] at 671–673 Boylston Street at 2:49:43 p.m. At the time of the first explosion, the race clock at the finish line showed 04:09:43,{{snd}}the elapsed time since the Wave 3 start{{explain|date=July 2018}} at 10:40 a.m. The second bomb exploded at 2:49:57 p.m., about 14 seconds later and one block farther west at 755 [[Boylston Street]]. The explosions took place nearly three hours after the winning runner crossed the finish line, but with more than 5,700 runners yet to finish. Windows on adjacent buildings were blown out but there was no structural damage. Runners continued to cross the line until 2:57 p.m. == Casualties and initial response == Rescue workers and medical personnel, on hand as usual for the marathon, gave aid as additional police, fire, and medical units were dispatched, including from surrounding cities as well as private ambulances from all over the state. The explosions killed 3 civilians and injured an estimated 264 others, who were treated at 27 local hospitals. At least 14 people required amputations, with some suffering [[traumatic amputation]]s as a direct result of the blasts. Police, following emergency plans, diverted arriving runners to [[Boston Common]] and [[Kenmore Square]]. The nearby [[The Lenox Hotel|Lenox Hotel]] and other buildings were evacuated. Police closed a 15-block area around the blast site; this was reduced to a 12-block crime scene on April 16. Boston police commissioner [[Edward F. Davis]] recommended that people stay off the streets. Dropped bags and packages, abandoned as their owners fled from the blasts, increased uncertainty as to the possible presence of more bombs. There were false reports of more bombs. An unrelated electrical fire at the [[John F. Kennedy Presidential Library and Museum|John F. Kennedy Presidential Library]] in nearby [[Dorchester, Boston|Dorchester]] was initially feared to be a bomb. [[File:2013 Boston Marathon explosions aftermath emergency services.jpg|thumb|left|Emergency services at work after the bombing]] The airspace over Boston was restricted, and departures halted from Boston's [[Logan International Airport]]. Some local transit service was halted as well. The [[Massachusetts Emergency Management Agency]] suggested people trying to contact those in the vicinity use text messaging instead of voice calls because of crowded cellphone lines. Cellphone service in Boston was congested but remained in operation, despite some local media reports stating that cell service was shut down to prevent cell phones from being used as detonators. The [[American Red Cross]] helped concerned friends and family receive information about runners and casualties. The [[Boston Police Department]] also set up a [[helpline]] for people concerned about relatives or acquaintances to contact and a line for people to provide information. [[Google Person Finder]] activated their disaster service under ''Boston Marathon Explosions'' to log known information about missing people as a publicly viewable file. Due to the closure of several hotels near the blast zone, a number of visitors were left with nowhere to stay; many Boston-area residents opened their homes to them. == Investigation == [[File:Pressure cooker bomb.jpg|thumb|This [[pressure cooker]] fragment was part of one of the explosive devices.]] The [[Federal Bureau of Investigation]] led the investigation, assisted by the [[Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives]], the [[Central Intelligence Agency]], the [[National Counterterrorism Center]], and the [[Drug Enforcement Administration]], and they named two official suspects. It was initially believed by some that [[North Korea]] was behind the attack after escalating tensions and threats with the U.S.http://www.businessinsider.com/north-korea-blamed-for-boston-bombings-2013-4?IR=Thttp://www.ibtimes.com/north-korea-denies-any-link-boston-marathon-bombs-says-it-still-may-strike-us-1211721 United States government officials stated that there had been no intelligence reports suggesting such an attack. Representative [[Peter T. King|Peter King]], a member of the [[United States House Permanent Select Committee on Intelligence|House Intelligence Committee]], said: "I received two top secret briefings last week on the current threat levels in the United States, and there was no evidence of this at all." The father of the two suspects claimed that the FBI had been watching his family, and that they questioned his sons in Cambridge, Massachusetts five times in relation to possible explosions on the streets of Boston.{{explain|reason=possible explosions?|date=July 2018}} [[File:Tsarnaev Fireworks.jpg|thumb|left|Emptied fireworks from Dzhokhar Tsarnaev's backpack, found in a landfill near the UMass Dartmouth campus]] Evidence found near the blast sites included bits of metal, nails, ball bearings, black nylon pieces from a backpack, remains of an electronic circuit board, and wiring. A [[pressure cooker]] lid was found on a nearby rooftop. Both of the [[improvised explosive device]]s were [[pressure cooker bomb]]s manufactured by the bombers. Authorities confirmed that the brothers used bomb-making instructions found in [[Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula]]'s ''[[Inspire (magazine)|Inspire]]'' magazine. After the suspects were identified, ''[[The Boston Globe]]'' reported that Tamerlan purchased [[fireworks]] from a fireworks store in [[New Hampshire]]. On April 19, the FBI, [[West New York]] Police Department, and [[Hudson County, New Jersey|Hudson County]] Sheriff's Department seized computer equipment from the apartment of the Tsarnaevs' sister in [[West New York, New Jersey]]. On April 24, investigators reported that they had reconstructed the bombs, and believed that they had been triggered by remote controls used for toy cars. {{Clear}} == April 18–19 shootings and manhunt == {{Infobox civilian attack | title=Tsarnaev brothers shootings and manhunt | image=File:Two suspects wanted by the FBI for the bombing.jpg | image_size=250px | alt= | caption=Security camera images of [[Tamerlan Tsarnaev]] (front) and [[Dzhokhar Tsarnaev]] just prior to the bombings | map= | map_size= | map_alt= | map_caption= | location='''Shooting:''' Corner of Vassar Street and Main Street in [[Cambridge, Massachusetts]]{{cite web|title=He loved us, and we loved him|url=http://web.mit.edu/newsoffice/2013/obit-officer-sean-collier-0419.html|publisher=MIT|accessdate= April 11, 2015}}
'''Firefight and manhunt:''' [[Watertown, Massachusetts]] | target= | date={{Nowrap|'''Shooting:'''}} {{Nowrap|April 18, 2013}}, {{Nowrap|10:48 p.m.}}
{{Nowrap|'''Firefight and manhunt:'''}} {{Nowrap|April 19, 2013,}} {{Nowrap|12:30 a.m.}} – {{Nowrap|8:42 p.m.}} | type={{Flatlist|[[Shootout]], [[Vehicle-ramming attack|vehicle ramming]], [[Lone wolf (terrorism)|lone wolf terrorism]]}} | fatalities= 3 (including Tamerlan Tsarnaev and a police officer who died April 10, 2014) | injuries= 16 | victim= | perp= | perpetrators= * [[Dzhokhar Tsarnaev]] (sentenced to death) * [[Tamerlan Tsarnaev]] (deceased) | perpetrator= | perps= | susperp= | weapons= * '''Shooting:''' [[9mm]] [[Ruger P series|Ruger P95]] [[semi-automatic pistol]] * '''Firefight:''' ** [[Improvised explosive device]]s ** [[9mm]] [[Ruger P series|Ruger P95]] [[semi-automatic pistol]] ** [[Carjacking|Stolen]] [[Mercedes-Benz M-Class]] [[SUV]] | numparts= | numpart= | dfens= | dfen= | footage= | motive= }} === Release of suspect photos === [[Jeff Bauman]] was immediately adjacent to one of the bombs and lost both legs; he wrote while in the hospital: "Bag, saw the guy, looked right at me". He later gave a detailed description which enabled the photo to be identified and circulated quickly. At 5:20 p.m. on April 18, the FBI released images of two suspects carrying backpacks, asking the public's help in identifying them. The FBI said that they were doing this in part to limit harm to people wrongly identified by news reports and on social-media. As seen on video, the suspects stayed to observe the chaos after the explosions, then walked away casually. The public sent authorities a deluge of photographs and videos, which were scrutinized by both authorities and online public [[social networking service|social networks]]. === MIT shooting and carjacking === [[File:Scenes and approximate times of events of April 18-19.jpg|thumb|upright=1.8|left|Scenes and approximate times of events of April 18–19]] A few hours after the photos were released, the Tsarnaev brothers shot Sean A. Collier of the [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology Police Department]] six times in an attempt to steal his gun, which they could not get out because of the holster's retention system.{{cite news|title=Police believe Tsarnaev brothers killed officer for his gun|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-18563_162-57581048/police-believe-tsarnaev-brothers-killed-officer-for-his-gun/|publisher=CBS News|date=April 23, 2013 |accessdate= April 11, 2015}} Collier, aged 27, was seated in his police car near the [[Stata Center]] (Building 32) on the [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]] campus. He died soon after. The brothers then [[carjacking|carjacked]] a [[Mercedes-Benz M-Class]] [[SUV]] in the [[Allston-Brighton]] neighborhood of Boston. Tamerlan took the owner, Chinese national Dun "Danny" Meng{{cite news|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/boston-marathon-bombing-jurors-see-dramatic-video-of-carjack-victims-escape/|title=Boston bombing jurors see dramatic video of carjack victim's escape|agency=CBS/[[Associated Press|AP]] | publisher=[[CBS News]] | date=March 12, 2015|accessdate=March 12, 2015}} ({{zh|c=孟盾}})Chinese name from: {{cite web|url=http://ny.uschinapress.com/weekends/2017/01-13/111620.html|title=《爱国者日》上映 再现波马爆炸案 留学生孟盾事迹搬...|publisher=''[[The China Press]]''|date=2017-01-13|accessdate=2018-09-22}}, hostage and told him that he was responsible for the Boston bombing and for killing a police officer. Dzhokhar followed them in the green Honda, later joining them in the Mercedes-Benz. Interrogation later revealed that the brothers "decided spontaneously" that they wanted to go to New York and bomb [[Times Square]]. The Tsarnaev brothers forced Meng to use his [[ATM card]]s to obtain $800 in cash. They transferred objects to the Mercedes-Benz and one brother followed it in their Honda Civic, for which an [[all-points bulletin]] was issued. While the Tsarnaev brothers stopped at a [[Shell Oil Company|Shell]] gas station, Meng escaped and ran across the street to the [[Mobil]] gas station, asking the clerk to call 911. His cell phone remained in the vehicle, allowing the police to [[Mobile phone tracking|focus their search]] on Watertown. === Watertown shootout === Shortly after midnight on April 19, [[Watertown, Massachusetts|Watertown]] police officer Joseph Reynolds identified the brothers in the [[Honda]] Civic and the stolen SUV. A gunfight followed between the brothers and police arriving at the scene on the 100 block of Laurel St. An estimated 200 to 300 rounds of ammunition were fired and at least one further bomb and several "crude [[grenade]]s" were thrown. According to Watertown Police Chief Edward Deveau, the brothers had an "[[arsenal]] of guns." Tamerlan ran out of ammunition and threw his empty pistol at Sergeant Jeffrey Pugliese, who tackled him with help from Sergeant John MacLellan.{{cite news|last1=DeWitt|first1=Vincent|title=Watertown Mass. Police describe takedown of Boston Marathon bombers|url=https://nypost.com/2013/07/08/exclusive-watertown-mass-police-describe-takedown-of-boston-marathon-bombers/|accessdate=26 March 2016|work=New York Post|date=8 July 2013}}{{cite news|last1=Smith|first1=Tovia|title=Filming For Marathon Bombing Movie Stirs Emotions In Boston|url=https://www.npr.org/2016/03/25/471755112/-its-going-to-trigger-lot-of-ptsd-boston-prepares-for-marathon-bombing-film|accessdate=26 March 2016|work=NPR|date=25 March 2016}} Tamerlan's younger brother Dzhokhar then drove the stolen SUV toward Tamerlan and police who unsuccessfully tried to drag Tamerlan out of his path; the car ran over Tamerlan and dragged him a short distance down the street.{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2312643/Boston-bomb-suspect-Commissioner-Ed-Davis-says-Dzhokhar-Tsarnaev-killed-brother.html |title=Boston bomb suspect: Commissioner Ed Davis says Dzhokhar Tsarnaev killed his brother|newspaper=Daily Mail|accessdate=April 22, 2013|location=London|first1=Snejana|last1=Farberov|first2=Paul|last2=Thompson|date=April 21, 2013}} Dzhokhar abandoned the car half a mile away and fled on foot. Tamerlan Tsarnaev died at 1:35 a.m. at a Boston hospital.{{cn|date=November 2017}} [[Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority]] Police Officer Richard H. Donohue Jr. was also critically wounded but survived.{{cite news |date=April 15, 2014 |title=Donohue Talks Miracle Survival On Toucher & Rich: 'I Don’t Have An Explanation For It' |url=http://boston.cbslocal.com/2014/04/15/dic-donohue-talks-miracle-survival-on-toucher-and-rich/ |newspaper=''CBS Boston'' |location= |publisher= |accessdate= }} Boston Police Department officer Dennis Simmonds was injured by a hand grenade and died April 10, 2014. Fifteen other officers were also injured. A later report by Harvard Kennedy School's Program on Crisis Leadership concluded that lack of coordination among police agencies had put the public at excessive risk during the shootout.{{cite news |last1=Schworm |first1=Peter |last2=Cramer |first2=Maria |date=April 30, 2013 |title=Harvard report praises response to Marathon bombings |url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/metro/2014/04/02/harvard-university-report-draws-lessons-from-marathon-bombings/qhXQcxi6jCxQqQnojtC3dP/story.html |newspaper=''[[The Boston Globe]]'' |location= |publisher= |accessdate= }} Only one firearm was recovered at the scene, a [[Ruger]] 9 mm pistol with a defaced serial number.{{cite news | first = Jack | last = Date | author2 = Matthew Mosk | title = Single Gun Recovered From Accused Bombers | date = April 24, 2013 | publisher = ABC News | url = http://abcnews.go.com/Blotter/single-gun-recovered-accused-boston-bombers/story?id=19028841#.UZTvOUbCSs3 | work = ABC The Blotter | accessdate = May 16, 2013}} === Identification and search for suspects === {{further|Dzhokhar Tsarnaev|Tamerlan Tsarnaev}} Records on the Honda left at the scene identified the men{{cite web|url=http://investigations.nbcnews.com/_news/2013/05/01/17991679-green-honda-could-prove-crucial-if-tsarnaev-charged-in-mit-officers-killing?lite |title=Green Honda could prove crucial if Tsarnaev charged in MIT officer's killing – Investigations |publisher=Investigations.nbcnews.com |date=August 29, 2010 |accessdate=July 24, 2013}} as two brothers whose family had immigrated to the United States seeking [[Right of asylum|political asylum]] around 2002: 26-year-old Tamerlan Tsarnaev and 19-year-old Dzhokhar "Jahar" Tsarnaev. The FBI released additional photos of the two during the Watertown incident. Early on April 19, Watertown residents received automated calls asking them to stay indoors. That same morning Governor Patrick asked residents of Watertown and adjacent cities and townsBoston, [[Belmont, Massachusetts|Belmont]], [[Brookline, Massachusetts|Brookline]], [[Cambridge, Massachusetts|Cambridge]], [[Newton, Massachusetts|Newton]], and [[Waltham, Massachusetts|Waltham]] to "[[shelter in place]]". [[Somerville, Massachusetts|Somerville]] residents also received automated calls instructing them to shelter in place. A 20-block area of Watertown was [[Cordon and search|cordoned off]] and residents were told not to leave their homes or answer the door, as officers scoured the area in tactical gear. Helicopters circled the area and [[SWAT]] teams in [[armored vehicles]] moved through in formation, with officers going door to door. On the scene were the FBI, the [[Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives]], [[United States Department of Homeland Security|the Department of Homeland Security]], [[National Guard of the United States|the National Guard]], the Boston and Watertown Police departments, and the [[Massachusetts State Police]]. The show of force was the first major field test of the interagency task forces created in the wake of the [[September 11 attacks]]. The entire [[Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority|public transit network]] and most Boston taxi services{{Efn|Taxi service was restored before the manhunt ended and transit service resumed.}} were suspended, as was [[Amtrak]] service to and from Boston. [[Logan International Airport]] remained open under heightened security. Universities, schools, many businesses, and other facilities were closed as thousands of law enforcement personnel participated in the door-to-door [[manhunt (law enforcement)|manhunt]] in Watertown, as well as following up other leads, including at the house that the brothers shared in Cambridge, where seven [[improvised explosive device]]s were found{{cite news|url=http://usnews.nbcnews.com/_news/2013/04/20/17823265-we-got-him-boston-bombing-suspect-captured-alive|title='We got him!': Boston bombing suspect captured alive|author=Williams|first=Pete|last2=Esposito|first2=Richard|date=April 8, 2015|work=NBC News|accessdate=April 8, 2015|last3=Isikoff|first3=Michael|last4=Connor|first4=Tracy}} The brothers' father spoke from his home in [[Makhachkala]], [[Dagestan]], encouraging his son to: "Give up. Give up. You have a bright future ahead of you. Come home to Russia." He continued, "If they killed him, then all hell would break loose." On television, Dzhokhar's uncle from [[Montgomery Village, Maryland]], pleaded with him to turn himself in. [[File:MissionHillCaptureCelebrations.jpg|thumb|Post-capture celebrations in Boston's student-heavy [[Mission Hill, Boston|Mission Hill]] neighborhood]] David Henneberry, a Watertown resident outside the search area, noticed that the tarp was loose on his parked boat on the evening of April 19, two hours after the shelter-in-place order had been lifted. He then saw a body lying inside the boat in a pool of blood. Authorities surrounded the boat and a police helicopter verified movement through a [[thermal imaging]] device. The figure inside the boat started poking at the tarp, and police shot at the boat. According to Boston Police Commissioner Ed Davis and Watertown Police Chief Deveau, Dzhokhar Tsarnaev was shooting at police from inside the boat, "exchanging fire for an hour".{{cite news |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2013/04/19/suspect-in-custody-newspaper-says/2095845/ |access-date=April 20, 2013 |title=As manhunt ends, new questions emerge in Boston bombings |author=Johnson, Kevin |work=USA Today |date=April 20, 2013}} A subsequent report indicated that the firing lasted for a shorter time.{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/officials-boston-suspect-had-no-firearm-when-barrage-of-bullets-hit-hiding-place/2013/04/24/376fc8a0-ad18-11e2-a8b9-2a63d75b5459_story.html|title=Officials: Boston suspect had no firearm when barrage of bullets hit hiding place|first1=Sari|last1=Horwitz|first2=Peter|last2=Finn|date=April 24, 2013|publisher=|access-date=October 15, 2017|via=www.WashingtonPost.com}} The suspect was found to have no weapon when he was captured. He was arrested at 8:42 p.m. and taken to [[Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center]], where he was listed in [[Medical state#Serious|critical condition]] with gunshot wounds to the head, neck, legs, and hand. Initial reports that the neck wound represented a suicide attempt were contradicted by his being unarmed. The situation was chaotic according to a police source quoted by the ''[[Washington Post]]'', and the firing of weapons occurred during "the fog of war". A subsequent review by the Commonwealth of Massachusetts provided this more specific summary: "One officer fired his weapon without appropriate authority in response to perceived movement in the boat, and surrounding officers followed suit in a round of 'contagious fire', assuming they were being fired on by the suspect. Weapons continued to be fired for several seconds until on scene supervisors ordered a ceasefire and regained control of the scene. The unauthorized shots created another dangerous crossfire situation".{{cite web |url=http://www.mass.gov/eopss/docs/mema/after-action-report-for-the-response-to-the-2013-boston-marathon-bombings.pdf |title=After Action Report for the Response to the 2013 Boston Marathon Bombings |date=December 2014 |website=Government of Massachusetts |publisher=Executive Office of Public Safety and Security |access-date=October 10, 2017 |quote=Improvement Area 4, Lack of Weapons Discipline, page 114}} == Legal proceedings == === Interrogation === United States Senators [[Kelly Ayotte]], [[Saxby Chambliss]], [[Lindsey Graham]], and [[John McCain]], and Representative [[Peter T. King]] suggested that Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, a U.S. citizen, should be tried as an [[unlawful combatant|unlawful enemy combatant]] rather than as a criminal, potentially preventing him from obtaining [[Assistance of Counsel Clause|legal counsel]]. Others said that doing so would be illegal, including prominent American legal scholar and lawyer [[Alan Dershowitz]], and would jeopardize the prosecution. The government decided to try Dzhokhar in the federal criminal court system and not as an enemy combatant. Dzhokhar was questioned for 16 hours by investigators but stopped communicating with them on the night of April 22 after Judge Marianne Bowler read him a [[Miranda warning]]. Dzhokhar had not previously been given a Miranda warning, as federal law enforcement officials invoked the warning's [[public safety exception]].
